Still was the earth, and still th' aetherial plain,</br>Prospect involv'd in darkness fled the sight,</br>While nature yielded to the gloomy reign</br>Of Proserpine, black goddess of the night.</br>Then sleep dissolv'd in peace sad sorrows moan,</br>Then study, wrapt in thought, true pensive pleasure found alone.

'Twas then thy works, great Maro, charm'd my soul,</br>While quiver'd thro' the gloom the taper's light;</br>Thy muse each low idea did controul,</br>And brought Elizium to my raptur'd sight.</br>And when o'erpowr'd with sleep, thy heav'nly theme,</br>By Morpheus was renew'd in a delightful dream.

Methought I wander'd in a dreary vale,</br>O'erspread with umbrage thick of lofty trees;</br>Thro' whose dark shade the light could scarce prevail,</br>And scarcely could be felt the smallest breeze.</br>A riv'let mid' the vale did purling sound,</br>Save which, the horrid gloom a silence had profound.

Scarce had I wond'ring cast my eyes around,</br>When sudden seem'd the scene to gather light;</br>Bright beams of radiance shone upon the ground,</br>Refulgent glory made the valley bright.</br>And while amaz'd my soul was fill'd with fear,</br>An heav'nly female form descending did appear.

She seem'd a goddess of the heav'nly nine,</br>A mantle white as virgin snow she wore;</br>Her features with a lustre shone divine,</br>Enchanting smiles her looks benignant bore.</br>A wreath of bays her lofty temples crown'd,</br>Her left hand held a lyre, which sweetly she did sound.

Loose did her spotless robe on aether flow,</br>From which elysian odours breath'd delight;</br>At last with solemn pace advancing slow,</br>On the soft ground she gently did alight.</br>Then the sweet music of the lyre she broke,</br>And thus, in terms divine, the blissful goddess spoke.

"Know, mortal, from those blessed seats I come,</br>Where happy bards receive their high reward;</br>Where, after life, those poets find an home,</br>Whose praise on earth the worthless did retard.</br>'Tis I who paint the path to deathless fame,</br>Belov'd by gods and men, Calliope my name.

"To you 'tis given those wond'rous scenes to know,</br>Which from the most of mortals are conceal'd,</br>Which Maro's pen sublime in part could shew,</br>And which to you shall also be reveal'd.</br>For this I left those happy seats of joy,</br>Where spring eternal reigns, where pleasures never cloy."

The goddess ceas'd — while lowly to the ground,</br>Methought I prostrate fell and strove to speak;</br>When lo!  my pow'rs in rapture lost profound,</br>'Twas vainly silence I essay'd to break.</br>And while my soul for speech could make no room,</br>The goddess gracious, thus did her discourse resume.

"Thy inmost thoughts I know — nor think the pow'r</br>Of converse unrestrain'd — thou hast with me</br>While rapt in chains of earthly flesh impure,</br>Thy spirit soars not from its prison free.</br>Nor canst thou follow me where I shall go,</br>Till thus I make thy soul its mortal bonds forego."

Scarce had she said — when from that purling brook</br>Which wander'd thro' the bosom of the vale,</br>In her fair hand some chrystal drops she took,</br>Which thrice she sprinkl'd on my body frail.</br>And mutt'ring words in magic language strange,</br>Sudden methought my form did feel a wond'rous change.

As when bright Sol, in sultry summer, fires</br>The womb of nature with his potent rays,</br>Some grov'ling locust he with wings inspires,</br>Which strait upon its purple pinions plays.</br>Elated — conscious of the glorious change,</br>Thro' fields of aether proud it then aspires to range.

So when the goddess us'd her potent charm,</br>My soul no more did pow'r of sense supply;</br>The vital lamp no more my frame could warm,</br>And then methought I knew what 'tis to die.</br>Till sudden springing from its mortal tomb,</br>My joyful spirit sought new freed in air to roam.

"Come let us rise — and leave this hateful place,"</br>The goddess said — and took me by the hand,</br>When straight methought with a peculiar grace,</br>My wings newform'd I spread at her command.</br>No more embarrass'd but elate and gay,</br>With her thro' yielding air joyful I soar'd away.

Then as sublime we cross'd th' ethereal plain,</br>Num'rous fair isles and kingdoms we survey'd,</br>Where wilehome Venus held her gentle reign,</br>Sweet Cyprus first beneath us was display'd.</br>But ah, no Paphos now can bless the sight,</br>From thence the Loves are fled, and ev'ry soft delight!

Next o'er the thunderer's fav'rite isle we press'd,</br>Imperial Crete, where Jove himself did reign,</br>Ah faded Isle, no more thy glories last,</br>No more an hundred cities make thee vain,</br>Barbarian hands thy temples have destroy'd,</br>And all thy beauties now dire ruin renders void.

Then o'er th' Egean we pursu'd our way,</br>Whose fruitful bosom teems with verdant isles;</br>On whose white cliffs the Nine wou'd frequent play,</br>Which once were favour'd with the muse's smiles.</br>But now no lays enchanting charm us there,</br>While shrieks of woe, instead, torment the frighted air.

Where twining ivy crawls o'er marble fanes,</br>Where dreary ruins spread a solemn gloom;</br>There did we view sad Athens, thy remains,</br>And viewing mourn'd thy lamentable doom;</br>Near thee thy fav'rite bird remain'd alone,</br>And faithful, hov'ring o'er thy ruins made her moan.

Where fair Boeotia's ample plains extend</br>Parnassus' heights at last appear'd in view,</br>Blest heights, which laurels ever green defend</br>From wintry storms, and verdure chilling dew;</br>No tainted blasts the sacred mount profane,</br>Each rude attempt the nine for ever rend'ring vain.

Near to the mountain's foot a grove of trees</br>Dispens'd from umbrage thick, a grateful shade,</br>Whose leaves scarce trembl'd to the quiv'ring breeze,</br>While birds amid their boughs soft music made;</br>"(Here said the muse) our tour in air shall end,"</br>And here methought, on earth straightway we did descend.

Fair alleys did the beauteous grove divide,</br>Border'd with rows of cypress trees and yew;</br>Grottoes and caves romantic grac'd each side;</br>Round which the vine entwin'd with ivy grew.</br>Bright streams by tufts of moss in murmurs play'd,</br>While flow'rs, their scented hues, on each soft bank display'd.

Charm'd at the sight of such a beauteous scene,</br>Enraptur'd to the goddess thus I cried,</br>"Sure here the muses choice abodes are seen;</br>And happy bards departed here reside.</br>For sure the nine their followers must invite,</br>With them in seats like those for ever to delight."

I paus'd, and thus my heav'nly guide reply'd,</br>"Think not within the limits of those groves,</br>Or on yon' mount, the muses now reside</br>Rapine instead thro' all their verdure roves..</br>Base aliens having made a fatal prey,</br>Of those sweet seats, o'er which the muses once had sway.

"Unhappy Greece! — by slav'ry vile enchain'd,</br>No longer now the nurse of heav'nly lays;</br>Since tyrants steal the fame she once maintain'd;</br>Delights no more to crown desert with praise.</br>While freedom which with verse is ever blest,</br>By happier regions, now far distant, is possest.

"Sunk is that noble spirit which inspir'd</br>Those famous worthies she contain'd of old;</br>No prize Olympian renders worth admir'd,</br>And glory gone bright ardor waxes cold.</br>Barbarian hands her ancient pride have broke,</br>And now she quiet bends beneath the shameful yoke.

"When freedom fled — the nine departed too,</br>And favour'd Greece no longer with their smiles;</br>Forsook their haunts on Haemus' lofty brow,</br>Their sacred fountains and their fav'rite isles;</br>And now they seldom visit mortal day,</br>Save when to western climes perchance they bend their way.

"Beneath the surface of this earthly seat,</br>Where other skies a brighter light extend;</br>The nine for ever fix their last retreat,</br>From thence alone their mandates here they send.</br>There worthy poets meet a bright reward,</br>Crown'd with immortal bays, blest with the nine's regard.

"From earth to those blest seats a path descends,</br>For ever unperceiv'd by mortal Eye,</br>Thro' yonder mount the darksome road extends,</br>And here I warn you e're we draw more nigh;</br>Let not those phantoms vain your fear excite,</br>Which on the lonesome way will skim before your sight.

"Mark — never from my side a moment stray,</br>For various forms delusive will entice,</br>To lead you wand'ring from the surest way,</br>And some will seem to offer fair advice,</br>But ah, let no deceit your steps allure,</br>To quit my side for there you are alone secure."

The goddess ceas'd — and soon methought we drew</br>To where th' extremest limits of the grove</br>Display'd Parnassus, perfect to the view;</br>Whose brow appear'd above the clouds to rove,</br>While one strait passage op'ning in its side,</br>Seem'd in two equal parts the mountain to divide.

"Thro' here, resum'd the goddess, lies our way,</br>A passage ever veil'd from human sight,</br>Chear'd by no visits from the lightsome day;</br>Darkness involves it in eternal night:</br>Save what false lights enchanting shades supply,</br>To rob departed bards of wish'd for glory nigh."

Scarce said the muse when with a sudden spring,</br>Between the craggy rocks she forc'd her way,</br>Then calling me to follow straitway in,</br>Methought her orders swift I did obey.</br>And rushing both within the shades of night,</br>The chearful day we lost, and ev'ry fair delight.

Deep was the terror which my soul assail'd,</br>Soon as we enter'd on this gloomy road,</br>Such hideous hissings all around prevail'd;</br>Serpents seem'd here to fix their dire abode.</br>Not all those snakes, the furies might supply,</br>Methought could ere with this most horrid hissing vie.

Dismay'd and wond'ring I address'd my guide,</br>But scarcely had begun to urge my fear,</br>When lo a drove of dismal forms I spy'd,</br>Seeming to us direct as drawing near.</br>From them methought the direful hissing came,</br>While high above their heads did soar a glimm'ring flame.

Megre and wan the ghastly troop appear'd,</br>With pallid visages half starv'd and thin,</br>Some spitting venom, most malicious sneer'd,</br>While others with their teeth did horrid grin.</br>But in one hideous hiss united all,</br>While lances, shap'd like pens, they brandish'd dipt in gall.

When near they came, the muse contemptuous smil'd,</br>At which this ghastly band was sore enrag'd;</br>No more with scoffs and hissing they revil'd,</br>Sudden instead with lances war they wag'd.</br>But all their rage methought prov'd weak and vain,</br>Since not a dart they threw could ere afford us pain!

Their utmost efforts finding we defy'd,</br>At last those unsuccessful foes withdrew;</br>Yet as they fled they spit a pois'nous tide,</br>Which with their lances prov'd impotent too.</br>For how should poisons weak or darts annoy,</br>Those spirits pure whom death itself can ne'er destroy?

Soon as they fled, the muse I thus address'd,</br>"Oh may thy servant goddess blest enquire,</br>What were those forms which did our way molest,</br>Why did they seek our harm with so much ire?</br>Such horrid shapes I ne'er beheld before,</br>Nor ever did I hear so dismal an uproar."

"Those whom thou saw'st (replied the gracious muse,)</br>Dwelt once on earth and then were criticks named;</br>There fraught with ranc'rous hate they did abuse,</br>Each bard of merit and his works defam'd.</br>Envious of worth they felt an impious joy,</br>Rather than to befriend true genius — to destroy.

"For this the nine with justice pass'd their doom</br>Involv'd in woe to dwell for ever here;</br>Where now as heretofore amid the gloom,</br>They seek to fill the poet's soul with fear.</br>Who (if they fright him from the destin'd way,)</br>Far from Elysian joys must ever stray."

More would the muse have said — but shades deform,</br>With horrid yelling 'gan to strike mine ear;</br>In shape of duns and catchpoles some did storm,</br>(Such as of old made Phillips quake with fear.)</br>There Famine rag'd — Dependence sullen frown'd,</br>While wild Despair did shake her dart and stalk around.

But chief a buxom syren of deceit,</br>False Flatt'ry chaunted her insidious lays;</br>Eager my footsteps from the path to cheat,</br>Her drunken cup she offer'd fill'd with praise.</br>Which I had tasted all my senses drown'd,</br>Had in vain glory's arms for ever slept profound.

But still defended by my sacred guard,</br>Methought I brav'd the guile of all my foes;</br>'Till at the last in safety we repair'd,</br>To where Elizium's golden gates arose.</br>At her command the gates self-open'd flew,</br>And all the gloomy scenes evanish'd from my view.

Then what fair prospects rush'd upon my sight!</br>Bright cloudless skies wrapt in blue serene,</br>Unveil'd a landscape blooming with delight,</br>Scented with groves of never fading green.</br>Where blushing flow'rs and vegetable gold,</br>Sought thro' the leafy trees their beauties to unfold.

There on the margin of nectarious streams,</br>That thro' gay amaranthine flowrets crept,</br>Involved in transport of poetic dreams,</br>Some children of Apollo sweetly slept.</br>While others tun'd to varied lays their lyre,</br>And warbled as on earth the theme they lov'd to fire.

There gentle Ovid sung his am'rous strain,</br>There dove-ey'd Sappho tun'd her tender moan;</br>Mourning no more her love bestow'd in vain,</br>She found the youth (that once she sought) her own.</br>To umber'd shades there frequent they retire,</br>And quench in mutual love the warmth of fond desire.

Encircl'd by the jocund sons of wine,</br>Anacreon sat — with blushing roses crown'd;</br>Still as on earth, he quaff'd the juice divine,</br>His ev'ry care in tipsy revels drown'd.</br>Before the buxom bard in mazy dance,</br>A sportive syren warm'd his soul with frequent glance.

Beneath the shade of myrtle cover'd bow'rs,</br>Tibullus wander'd pensive all alone;</br>There Hammond with his Delia culling flow'rs,</br>Renew'd his tender elegiac moan!</br>While balmy zephyr whisp'ring thro' the grove,</br>To gentle eccho breath'd each plaintive tale of love.

High on a mount of laurel vested green,</br>Whose summits with refulgent roses shone;</br>Methought the muses 'mid a blooming scene,</br>Fix'd to eternity their lasting throne.</br>There each to lyre responsive lull'd the wind,</br>And with heroic lays in transport wrapt the mind.

Near to the nine methought those bards were plac'd,</br>Who reap'd with epic strains the laurell'd meed;</br>Homer divine who fair Achaia grac'd,</br>And he who sweetly touch'd the Mantuan reed.</br>There Milton tun'd with notes sublime his lyre,</br>And Tasso glow'd anew with bright romantic fire.

As nearer to the muse's seats we drew,</br>Celestial warblings charm'd the air around;</br>Sweeter than those the Theban satyrs knew,</br>When Orpheus sooth'd them with his silver sound.</br>All instruments of cadence softly clear,</br>Methought in those sweet strains were join'd the soul to chear.

But ah not long those blissful sounds did last,</br>Not long those lovely prospects blest mine eyes;</br>Shrill Chanticleer announc'd my vision past,</br>For crowing loud he bade the morn arise.</br>Starting I rais'd my head — the fairy theme,</br>Fled swift! — and strait I found the whole an empty dream!!</br>
